origin: A diabolo, qui est simia dei.
translation: From the devil, who is the ape of God.
equivalent: Where god has a church the devil will have his chapel.
meaning: "Very seldom does any good thing arise but there comes an ugly phantom of a caricature of it."

origin: Abbati, medico, patrono que intima pande.
translation: Reveal your intimates to your Abbot, a doctor, and a lawyer.
equivalent: Conceal not the truth from thy physician and lawyer.

translation: The absent will not be an heir.
equivalent: Out of sight, out of mind.
Deep calls to deep.
meaning: Deep thinking leads to deep understanding.

translation: He who preserves something, will have something.
equivalent: Sparing is the first gaining.
The remedy is often worse than the disease; Burn not your house to rid it of the mouse.

origin: Aegroto dum anima est, spes est.
translation: As long as a sick person is conscious, there is still hope.
equivalent: As long as there is life there is hope.

origin: Aeque pars ligni curvi ac recti valet igni.
equivalent: Crooked logs make straight fires.
Translation and Do what you do, in the sense of "Do well what you do", "Do well in whatever you do" or "Be serious in what you do"

translation: "If there is something [quid for aliquid] you do (well), carry on", "If you do something, do it well" see also "Age quod agis"
equivalent: Bloom where you are planted.

origin: Aliis si licet, tibi non licet.
translation: Don't you know, my son, with how little wisdom the world is governed?

origin: Aliquis in omnibus est nullus in singulis.
translation: Someone in all, is nothing in one.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 156. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Somebody who has a very wide range of abilities or skills usually does not excel at any of them."

translation: To make a hill from a sewer.
equivalent: Don't make a mountain out of a molehill.
meaning: Don't make something momentous out of a trifle.

translation: Yet it comes from urine.
Authority, not truth, makes law.
Fortune favors the brave.(Virgil, Aeneid 10, 284)
equivalent: Fortune favours the bold.
meaning: "Those who act boldly or courageously are most likely to succeed."

translation: Fortune favors the bold. (Motto of the 80 Fighter Squardon at Kunsan AB, ROK)

origin: Audi, vide, tace, si tu vis vivere (in pace).
translation: Hear, see, be silent, if you wish to live (in peace). Roman proverb, according to this.
equivalent: Rather see than hear.

translation: I'll either find a way or make one.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 299. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "If you are sufficiently determined to achieve something, then you will find a way of doing so."

origin: Basio saepe volam, cui plagam diligo solam.
translation: A lot kiss the palm of the hand which they wish to see gone.
equivalent: Many kiss the hand they wish cut off.

translation: War will feed on itself.
Something that is well diagnosed can be cured well.
equivalent: A disease known is half cured.

translation: He gives twice who gives promptly
equivalent: He gives twice, who gives in a trice.

origin: Brevis oratio penetrat coelos; Longa potatio evacuat scyphos.
translation: Short prayer pierces the heavens long empty drinking cups.
equivalent: Short prayers reach heaven.

origin: Caaus honoretur, puer ad documenta cidetur.
translation: Age should be honored, and their words documented.
equivalent: Gray hairs are honorable.

translation: "Seize the day." By Horace, Odes I,11,8, to Leuconoe: carpe diem, quam minimum credula postero ("take hold of the day, believing as little as possible in the next"). The verb "carpere" has the literal meaning "to pick, pluck," particularly in reference to the picking of fruits and flowers, and was used figuratively by the Roman poets to mean "to enjoy, use, make use of."

"Carthage must be destroyed." Actually, ceterum censeo Carthaginem esse delendam ("Apart from that, I conclude that Carthage must be destroyed") Cato the Elder used to end every speech of his to the Senate, on any subject whatsoever, with this phrase. Mentioned to indicate that someone habitually harps on one subject.
Beware the man of one book.
equivalent: Fear the man of one book.
meaning: "A man of one book" (that is, a man who reads only the same type of books) is indirectly dangerous to himself and others because of his ignorance.

origin: Cedens in uno cedet in pluribus.
translation: Yielding a single results in yielding in many.
Evil comes more quickly than it returns.
equivalent: Misfortune comes on horseback and goes away on foot.

translation: Quickly matured, quickly rotten.
equivalent: Early ripe, early rotten.
meaning: Precocious children will mean much trouble later on.

translation: Second thoughts are sounder.
equivalent: Second thoughts are best.

origin: Consilio, quod respuitur, nullum subest auxilium.
translation: He who can't be advised, can also not be helped.
equivalent: He that will not be counseled cannot be helped.
meaning: Advice often contain a genuine warning or an effective suggestion, which is unprudent not to take into consideration.

translation: The power of habit is great.
equivalent: Old habits die hard.

translation: Habit is second nature.
equivalent: Old habits die hard.

translation: Pride comes before fall.

origin: Cor boni concilii statue tecum non est enim tibi aliud pluris illo.
translation: Listen to people, but keep your own wits.
equivalent: Though thou hast ever so many counsellors, yet do not forsake the counsel of thy own soul.

translation: The greater the degeneration of the republic, the more of its laws. (Tacitus)
He who waits, despairs.
equivalent: Source for meaning of English equivalent:Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 120. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Do not pin all your hopes on something you may not attain, because you could end up with nothing."

translation: Believe that you have it, and you do.
equivalent: Fake it till you make it.

origin: Cui caput dolet, omnia membra languent.
translation: When the head is sick, all members mourn.
equivalent: When the head is sick, the whole body is sick.

origin: Cuiusvis hominis est errare, nullius nisi insipientis in errore perseverare.
translation: Any man can make a mistake; only a fool keeps making the same one.
meaning: Do not do the same thing and expect a different result.

translation: Sorrow makes gray hairs before the time.
equivalent: Fretting cares make grey hairs.
meaning: Worrying is a negative activity that can age you prematurely.

origin: Custode et cura natura potentior omni.
equivalent: Nature is beyond all teaching.
There is no accounting for taste.
translation: "There's no arguing about tastes and colors."

equivalent: Whom God will destroy, he first make mad.

translation: Celebrate the day when it is evening.
meaning: Don't celebrate untill you are 100 % sure there is a reason to do so.; Don't count your chickens before they're hatched.

origin: Difficile est longum subito deponere amorem.
equivalent: True love never grows old.

translation: Gods help those who do.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Paczolay, Gyula (1997). European Proverbs in 55 languages. DeProverbio.com. p. 150. ISBN 1-875943-44-7.
meaning: "When in trouble first of all every one himself should do his best to improve his condition."

origin: Dives aut iniquus est, aut iniqui heres.
equivalent: No one gets rich quickly if he is honest.

origin: Dives est qui sibi nihil deesse putat.
translation: The rich man is the one who thinks to himself that nothing was lacking.
equivalent: Wealth rarely brings happiness.

translation: Divide and govern [or conquer]. Attributed to Julius Caesar.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 57. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 13 August 2013.
meaning: "The best way to conquer or control a group of people is by encouraging them to fight among themselves rather than allowing them to unite in opposition to the ruling authority."

translation: We learn by teaching. (Seneca)

equivalent: Good riding at two anchors, men have told, for if the one fails, the other may hold.

translation: Lead by Example.

origin: Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori.
translation: It is sweet and honorable to die for the fatherland. By Horace, Odes III, 2, 13, frequently quoted on war memorials, and notably in the poem Dulce Et Decorum Est by Wilfred Owen, who calls it "the old lie".
Sweet is the apple when the keeper is away.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 93. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Things that you must not have or do are always the most desirable."

origin: Dulcior illa sapit caro, quae magis ossibus haeret.
equivalent: The sweetest flesh is near the bones.

origin: Dum canem caedimus, corrosisse dicitur corrium.
translation: If you want to beat a dog you will easily find a stick.
meaning: Someone who wants to be mean will find things to be mean about no matter what.

origin: Dum satur est venter, gaudet caput inde libenter.
translation: When the belly is full, the head is pleased.
equivalent: Full stomach, contented heart.

translation: "As long as I breathe, I hope." Translated as "While I breathe, I hope" the motto of the State of South Carolina [[1]]
equivalent: As long as there is life there is hope.

translation: While we live, let us live!
While there is life, there is hope.

origin: Ecce omnis, qui dicit vulgo proverbium, in te assumet illud dicens: Sicut mater, ita et filia ejus.
translation: Such mother, such daughter.
equivalent: Like mother, like daughter.
meaning: "Daughters may look and behave like their mothers. This is due to inheritance and the example observed closely and daily."

translation: Effect follows a reason.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 80. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 22 September 2013.
meaning: "Everything has an underlying reason."

origin: Eodem cubito, eadem trutina, pari libra.
translation: The elbow, the same balance, an equal balance.
equivalent: Whatever measure you deal out to others will be dealt back to you.

translation: A heap is made from grains.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 77. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 20 September 2013.
meaning: "All contributions, however small, are of use."

translation: "And knowledge itself, is power" (Francis Bacon, Meditationes sacrae)

origin: Ex malis moribus bonae leges natae sunt.
translation: Bad customs have given birth to good laws.
equivalent: Good laws have sprung from bad customs.

translation: "Nothing comes from nothing" (you need to work for something; also the Conservation Law in philosophy and modern science) (Lucretius). This is also a famous Shakespeare quote in King Lear.

equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 112. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "People who know they have done wrong reveal their guilt by the things they say or the way they interpret what other people say."

translation: Extreme remedies for extreme ills.
equivalent: Desperate diseases must have desperate remedies.
meaning: "Drastic action is called for – and justified – when you find yourself in a particularly difficult situation."

translation: Waiting for the grass the cow dies.
equivalent: While the grass grows the steed starves.
meaning: Dreams or expectations may be realized too late.

translation: The descent into hell is easy.
Deeds, then I may believe you.
equivalent: No need of words, trust deeds.
meaning: "Actions may be, and indeed sometimes are deceptive in a measure though not as much so as words; and accordingly are received in general as more full and satisfactory proofs of the real disposition and character of persons than verbal expressions."

translation: "Make haste slowly" (i.e. proceed quickly but with caution, a motto of Augustus Caesar).
meaning: Do your work slowly in order to get it done properly.
equivalent: More speed less haste.
Confidence begets confidence.
meaning: Confidence spills over to your coworkers.

translation: Trust nobody/no one.
equivalent: Distrust is the mother of safety
meaning: Trust no one except yourself; Trust, but verify.

translation: Fortune favors the brave. (cf. Audaces fortuna iuvat.) (Terence)

origin: Frans hominum ad perniciem, et integritas ad salutem, vocat.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 128. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Being honest or telling the truth is always the wisest course of action."

equivalent: Appearances deceive.
meaning: Things are not always as they appear.

origin: Generosus equus non curat canem latrantem
translation: "A well-bred horse doesn't care about a barking dog.": "The dogs bark but the caravan passes on."
meaning: Let the world say what it will.

translation: It is glorious to forget injustice.
equivalent: Forgive and forget.

translation: A drop hollows out the stone. (Ovid, Epistles)

origin: Gutta cavat lapidem non bis, sed saepe cadendo; sic homo fit sapiens non bis, sed saepe legendo.
translation: A drop hollows out the stone by falling not twice, but many times; so too is a person made wise by reading not two, but many books.(Giordano Bruno, Il Candelaio)

origin: Gutta cavat lapidem non vi, sed saepe cadendo
translation: A drop hollows out the stone not by force, but falling many times. (original latin proverb).
"History is the tutor of life.”
"What's to me today, tomorrow to you.”
equivalent: The door swings both ways; What goes around comes around.

translation: "Men believe what they want to." (Julius Caesar)
Man proposes but God disposes.
meaning: Things often don't turn out as you have planned.

translation: Honor follows the fleeing.
equivalent: Follow glory and it will flee, flee glory and it will follow thee.
Good blood always shows itself.

translation: Gifts of enemies are no gifts.
equivalent: Beware of Greeks bearing gifts.
meaning: "Do not trust gifts or favors if they come from an enemy."

translation: Fortune disdains the lazy.
meaning: Laziness deceives wisdom.

translation: Ignorance of the law is no excuse.
To rule yourself is the ultimate power. (Seneca)

origin: Improbe Neptunum accusat, qui iterum naufragiam facit.
equivalent: He complains wrongfully at the sea that suffer shipwreck twice.
meaning: Don't do the same thing again and expect different results.

translation: When in doubt, abstain.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 296. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "If you are unsure what to do, it is best to do nothing at all."

translation: "When in doubt, in favour of the accused". (Corpus Juris Civilis)
Hasty judgments are criminal.
equivalent: Hasty judgment leads to repentance.
meaning: A quick evaluation is a terrible evaluation.

origin: In necessariis unitas, in dubiis libertas, in omnibus caritas
translation: "In necessary things unity, in doubtful things liberty, in all things charity" (often misattributed to St Augustine).

origin: In nullum avarus bonus est, in se pessimus.
equivalent: The covetous man is good to none and worst to himself.

origin: In propria causa nemo debet esse iudex.
translation: No one should be the judge in his own trial.
equivalent: No one can be the judge in his own case.
A fool is ever laughing.

translation: There is truth in vine.
equivalent: In wine there is truth.
meaning: Alcohol consumed removes the inhibition against telling the truth that occasionally one would like to keep secret.

origin: Inimicum quamvis humilem docti est metuere.

translation: Children bring with them countless cares.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 40. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 2 August 2013.
meaning: "Children are bound to cause their parents anxiety, and may or may not also bring them joy."

origin: Intemperans adulescentia effetum corpus tradit senectuti.
equivalent: They who would be young when they are old must be old when they are young.
Don't go between the tree and the bark.
meaning: Do not interfere when two parts are having an argument.

equivalent: ”A fool may give a wise man counsel.”

translation: "Anger is brief insanity" (Horace, epistles I, 2, 62).
meaning: If you are mad, count to twenty.

origin: Iter per praecepta longum, per exempla, breve et efficax.
equivalent: Example is better than precept.
A problem shared is a problem halved.

translation: "Truth is hidden, but nothing is more beautiful than the truth”
You are lending light to the sun.

origin: Macte animo! Generose puer sic itur ad astra!
translation: "Be strong, young man! Through this way one gets to the stars." (Motto of the Brazilian Air Force Academy)
"Weeds grow fast.”

equivalent: Shame take him that shame thinketh.
meaning: Don't think evil of others since they most likely act the way they do because of situational factors: Never attribute something to malice which can adequately be explained by stupidity.

translation: Bad beginnings lead to bad results.
equivalent: A bad beginning makes a bad ending.
meaning: "It is as impossible that a system radically erroneous, once commenced, should end well, as it is that a mathematical problem, commenced wrong, should come out right."

origin: Malum consilium quod mutari non potest.
translation: "It is a bad plan that cannot be changed (A plan that cannot be changed is a bad one).”
For a tough knot take a blunt wedge.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 53. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 10 August 2013.
meaning: "Drastic action is called for – and justified – when you find yourself in a particularly difficult situation."

origin: Malum quidem nullum esse sine aliquo bono.
translation: "There is, to be sure, no evil without something good.”
equivalent: Every cloud has its silver lining.

translation: "One hand washes the other.”
"Necessity is the mother of invention" (Apuleius)
"One owes the greatest possible care for the child" (Juvenal)
"The doctor cares [for his patient], nature heals [him]." or "Doctor cures, nature saves”

origin: Melium est nomen bonum quam divitae multae.
equivalent: A good name is the best of all treasures.

translation: Remember that you are going to die
meaning: You won't live forever, so make sure you do things which are really entertaining or really important.

equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 167. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Liars must remember the untruths they have told, to avoid contradicting themselves at some later date."

equivalent: His own desire leads every man.

translation: It is a wreteched fate which is absent enemies.
equivalent: If you have no enemies it is a sign that fortune has forgotten you; People throw stones only at trees with fruit on them.
Translation and Proffered service stinks.

translation: "Woman is man's ruin."

equivalent: Source for meaning of Keating, Walter (1859). Proverbs of All Nations. W. Kent & Company (late D. Bogue). p. 128.
meaning: "Much ado about nothing."

translation: The world desires to be deceived; therefore it is. (Attributed to Petronius)
equivalent: The world wants to be taken in.

translation: "Do not give a child a sword."
meaning: Let every person act in his proper sphere of life.

origin: Ne quid expectes amicos, quod tute agere possis.
translation: Expect nothing from friends, do what you can do yourself.
equivalent: For what thou canst do thyself, rely not on another.

translation: "Nothing too much", moderation in all thing (Terence)

"Shoemaker, not above the sandal", do not talk about things you know nothing of (attributed to Apelles (352-308 BC), the famous Greek painter. He had asked a cobbler to view a painting he was working on to help him (Apelles) paint the sandals correctly. The cobbler explained what was wrong with the sandals, but then began to criticize other aspects of the painting. Apelles stopped him with this famous line, meaning that, while the cobbler was certainly an expert at making shoes, he was not qualified to offer opinions as to anything else---particularly art.)

origin: Nemo regere potest nisi qui et regi.
equivalent: Who has not served cannot command.

translation: "No one is a judge in his own case".
"You know not what night-fall may bring."

equivalent: Take counsel of one's pillow.

origin: Non capiunt lepores tympana rauca leves.
equivalent: Drumming is not the way to catch a hare.
meaning: Don't expect anyone to change his ways by scolding him.

equivalent: Do not think that one enemy is insignificant, or that a thousand friends are too many.

translation: "We are not born for ourselves alone”
meaning: Each one of us carries a responsibility for the whole world.

translation: "It [money] doesn't smell" (according to Suetonius, Emperor Vespasian was challenged by his son Titus for taxing the public lavatories, the emperor held up a coin before his son and asked whether it smelled)

origin: Non opus est follo suspendere tympana collo.
translation: A fool does not need any bells.
equivalent: A tongue of a fool carves a piece of his heart to all that sit near him.

origin: Non quia difficilia sunt non audemus, sed quia non audemus, difficilia sunt.
translation: "It is not because things are difficult that we do not dare, but because we do not dare, things are difficult." (Seneca, Letter to Lucilius, letter 104, section 26, line 5)
"We learn not for school but for life." (Seneca's original quotation is "Non vitae, sed scholae discimus.”)
"It will not always be summer." (be prepared for hard times)
"No punishment without a law.”
"No rule without exception.”

origin: Nulli tacuisse nocet, tutum silentii premium.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Porter, William Henry (1845). Proverbs: Arranged in Alphabetical Order .... Munroe and Company. pp. 125.
meaning: "In private animosities and verbal contentions, where angry passions are apt to rise, and irritating, if not profane expressions are often made use of, as we sometimes see to be the case, not only among neighbors, but in families, between husbands and wives, or parents and children, or the children themselves and other members of the household, - the least said, the better in general. By multiplying words, cases often grow worse instead of better."

origin: Nullus est liber tam mallus, ut non aliqua parte prosit.
equivalent: No book was so bad, but some good might be got out of it.
meaning: You might typically get something good out of an overall faulty book, especially a non fictional one, such as sound advice or anecdotes to tell others.

translation: Seize the offer.
equivalent: When the pig is proffered, hold up the poke.
meaning: We should accept the offers that has been given us.

translation: Obscurity envelops truth. (Virgil).
equivalent: Truth gives a short answer, lies go round about.
Take heed of enemies reconciled and of meat twice boiled.
meaning: Your former enemies might cunningly take revenge on you just out of spite.; Trust not a reconciled enemy more than an open foe.

translation: Eyes are the index of the mind.
equivalent: The eye looks but it is the mind that sees.

translation: All things (in rome) have their price. original "omnia Romae cum pretio" Juvenal

origin: Omnibus se accomodat rebus, omnia novit.

translation: Medicine is the noblest of all arts.

equivalent: Grey hairs are honorable.
Poets are born, but orators are trained.
meaning: Some things can be improved by training, others require innate talent.

equivalent: Good swimmers are often drowned.
meaning: Beware of letting your competence lead you into overconfidence.

translation: Rest is the best medicine.

equivalent: Idle hands are the devils playthings.
meaning: If you are bored or idle, start doing some work.

translation: "Agreements must be honoured.”

origin: Pars est beneficii quod petitur si cito neges.
translation: A prompt refusal has in part the grace of a favour granted.

origin: Pax melior est quam iustissimum bellum.
translation: "Peace is better than the most just war.”
"Punishment comes limping."
equivalent: Punishment is lame, but it comes.

translation: [There's] danger in delay. (Livy)
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 53. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 10 August 2013.
meaning: "Hesitation or procastination may lead to trouble or disaster."

translation: "A beard doesn't make a philosopher." (Plutarch)
meaning: Mere formal signs of authority does not make one.

translation: The large fishes eats the small ones.
meaning: "Small organizations or insignificant people tend to be swallowed up or destroyed by those that are greater and more powerful."

origin: Post prandium stabis, post coenam ambulabis.
translation: "After dinner, rest a while, after supper walk a mile."
"Better late then never" (Livy)
"Forewarned (is) forearmed”
Milk today, for what you are aiming for is fleeing.
equivalent: One today is worth two tomorrows.
Prevention is better than cure.
meaning: Precaution is infinitely better than remedial measures.

equivalent: Forewarned, forearmed.

translation: Provided common, commonly true.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 45. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 4 August 2013.
meaning: A general disrepute is often true.

origin: Pulverulenta novis bene verritur area scopis.
equivalent: "New brooms sweep clean."
meaning: Newcomers are the most ambitious.

translation: Like king, like people.
What pay, such work.
equivalent: You get what you pay for.

origin: Quam bene vivas refert, non quam diu.
translation: How well you live makes a difference, not how long. (Seneca)
As much as needed, enough.

"Whom the gods love dies young" (Plautus, Bacchides, IV, 7, 18). In the comic play, a sarcastic servant says this to his aging master. The rest of the sentence reads: dum valet, sentit, sapit, "while he is full of health, perception and judgement.”
"Whom the gods hated, they made them pedagogues”
"He who sleeps does not sin”
"Those who have ears to hear, hear!" (Vulgate, Matthew 11:15)
equivalent: Nature gave us two ears and one mouth.

origin: Qui non est hodie, eras minus aptus erit.
equivalent: Source for meaning of English equivalent:Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 120. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Take advantage of an opportunity when it presents itself, even if you do not want or need it at the time, because it may no longer be available when you do."

origin: Quien me amat, amet et canum meum.
equivalent: Love me, love my dog.
meaning: If you love someone, you will virtually like everything about him.

translation: He who dares wins.
He who has much desires more. (Seneca)

equivalent: Don't have too many irons in the fire.

translation: "He who does not go forward, loses ground." or "He who does not accomplish anything, is a failure/has shortcomings.”
equivalent: He who does not advance goes backwards.

origin: Qui pro innocente dicit, satis est eloquens.
translation: "He who speaks for the innocent is eloquent enough." (Publilius Syrus)
"(One) who asks, doesn't err.”
equivalent: The only stupid question is the one not asked.

translation: "Who writes, reads twice.”

origin: Qui tacet consentire videtur, ubi loqui debuit ac potuit.
translation: "Who is silent, when he ought to and might have spoken, is seen to agree.”
"He who transplanted still sustains." (motto of Connecticut referring to the transplantation of settlers from England to the New World.)

origin: Qui vitulum tollit, taurum subduxerit idem .
equivalent: He that steals an egg will steal an ox.

origin: Qui vult dare parva non debet magna rogare.
translation: "He who wishes to give little shouldn't ask for much.”

origin: Quidquid agis, prudenter agas, et respice finem!
translation: Whatever you do, may you do it prudently, and look to the end!
equivalent: Whatever you do, act wisely, and consider the end.

translation: "Whatever you learn, you learn it for yourself.”
"Whatever is said in Latin seems profound."
"Don't move settled things" (i.e. "Don't rock the boat", "Let sleeping dogs lie.”)
"Who will watch the watchers themselves?" or "Who will guard the guardians themselves?" (Juvenal)
What is asserted gratuitously may be denied gratuitously.
"That which harms, often teaches”
meaning: Unpleasant experiences will make you wiser.
equivalent: What does not kill you makes you stronger.
Opportunity knocks only once.

translation: If you know what you are talking about, then words came along. (Marco Porcio Catón)
"Repetition is useful", or "Repeating things helps”.
Repetition is the mother of study.

origin: Roma die uno non aedificata est
translation: Rome wasn't built in a day.
The well-being of the patient is the most important law.
Let the welfare of the people be the supreme law. (motto of the U.S. state of Missouri).
Dare to be wise. (Horace) (Motto of the University of New Brunswick)
A wise (man) will rule (or possibly, be ruled by) the stars.
A wise man takes everything he owns with himself. (i.e. in his head, his wealth is his wisdom)
meaning: Material asssets are fleeting, but intellectual assets will basically stay with you the rest of your life. Therefore, intellectual assets are much more worth than material ones.
equivalent: A good mind possess a kingdom.

origin: Sapientia abscondita et thesaurus invisus quae utilitas in utrisque.
translation: The hidden things of wisdom and a treasure that is not seen, what profit is in them both?
equivalent: Money is there to be spent.

translation: Wisdom is power.

origin: Scientia non habet inimicum nisi ignorantem.
translation: Knowledge has no enemies but the ignorant.

origin: Senatores boni viri, senatus autem mala bestia
translation: Senators are good men, however Senate is a malicious animal

origin: Sermo hominum mores et celat et indicat idem.
equivalent: Men talk only to conceal the mind.

origin: Sepem vir calcat ibi plus ubi passio exstat.
equivalent: Men leap over where the hedge is lower.
meaning: Always do things in a way that requires the absolut least amount of labor.

origin: Serpens, nisi serpentem comederit, non fit draco.
translation: A serpent, if it does not devour a serpent, does not become a dragon.

origin: Si cazares, no te alabes; si no cazares, no te enfades.
equivalent: If fortune favours, beware of being exalted; if fortune thunders, beware of being overwhelmed.

origin: Si fueris Romae, Romano vivito more, si fueris alibi, vivito sicut ibi.
translation: If you are in Rome, live in the Roman way, if you are somewhere else, live like there. (attributed to Ambrose of Milan)
equivalent: When in Rome, do as the Romans.

origin: Si hîc esses, seires qua me vellicent.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 289. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "Nobody can fully understand another person's hardship or suffering."

translation: "Greatness from Small Beginnings."
"During war, laws are silent." (Cicero)

equivalent: Like will to like.

translation: "If you want peace, prepare for war."
"If you want peace, prepare justice."
"Laws are silent in times of war"

origin: Simia est simia, etiasmi purpura vestiatur.
equivalent: "A golden bit does not make the horse any better."
meaning: An ugly thing will remain ugly even if its appeareance is taken care of.

origin: Stultorum est se alienis immiscere negotiis.
equivalent: Give neither salt nor counsel till you are asked for it.

translation: "More law, less justice." (Cicero, De officiis I, 10, 33)
"Works are harder than words."
equivalent: "Easier said than done."

origin: Sunt pueri pueri pueri puerilia tractant
translation: "Boys are boys and boys will act like boys."
equivalent: Boys will be boys.

translation: "Cobbler, no further than the sandal!" I.e. don't offer your opinion on things that are outside your competence. It is said that the Greek painter Apelles once asked the advice of a cobbler on how to render the sandals of a soldier he was painting. When the cobbler started offering advice on other parts of the painting, Apelles rebuked him with this phrase (but in Greek).
To each its own is beautiful.
equivalent: The bird loves her own nest.

translation: "For those who come late, only the bones."
Times should be adapted to.
equivalent: Take things as you find them.
meaning: Adapt yourself to new surroundings or conditions. For instance, if you are ill, do what you still can instead of waiting to get healthy.

translation: "Save time!"
"Time flees." (i.e., "time flies"). Originally as Sed fugit interea, fugit irreparabile tempus - translation: "Meanwhile the irreplaceable time flees" (Virgil)
equivalent: Time and tide waits for none.

translation: "Time flees, eternity dwells."
"Time flees, love stays"
"The cause of fear is ignorance." (Seneca)
"Three makes a company."
"Take up and read; take up and read!" (Augustinus)

origin: Tunc tua res agitur, paries cum proximus ardet.
translation: "It also concerns you when the nearest wall is burning."

equivalent: What goes around comes around.
meaning: Good acts quite often reward themselves. Conversely, bad acts quite often punish themselves.

translation: "Where one feels good, there is one's country."
"Where there is harmony, there is victory."
"Where there is doubt, there is freedom." legal, meaning when in doubt the prisoner has to be freed.
"Where there's smoke, there's fire."
meaning: Where there are the signs of something, something is there.

origin: Ulula cum lupis, cum quibus esse cupis.
translation: "Who keeps company with wolves, will learn to howl."
meaning: You will become like the people you surround yourself with.

translation: Do not commit all to one boat.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 63. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5. Retrieved on 18 August 2013.
meaning: "Spread your risks or investments so that if one enterprise fails you will not lose everything."

translation: "One swallow doesn't make spring"
meaning: A solitary event is no indication that a major change is taking place.

translation: For one reprimand, a hundred corrections."
"Experience is the best teacher." (i.e., "Practice makes perfect.")
"Be amiable, then you'll be loved."

origin: Ut desint vires, tamen est laudanda voluntas
translation: "Even if the powers are missing, the will deserves praise" (Ovid)
"You'll reap what you sow." (Cicero, "De oratore"); The Bible Job 4:8; Galatians 6:7.
equivalent: What you reap is what you sow.

origin: Ut sis nocte levis, sit cena brevis!
translation: "That your sleeping hour be peaceful, let your dining hour be brief!" (Sis is one hour before sunset.) (modern: Sleep hard, Sleep fast, Sleep well)

origin: Uxor formosa et vinum sunt dulcia venena.
translation: "Beautiful women and wine are sweet venom."
Change pleases.
Empty pots make the most noise.
equivalent: It is not the hen that cackles the most that lay the most eggs.
meaning: It is not he who advertises for himself that can achieve the greatest results.

translation: Go even against the flow.
Words instruct, illustrations lead.
Words fly, written stays.
equivalent: Paper is forbearing.

origin: Verit eo caudam, qua decidit arbore, malum.
equivalent: The apple does not fall far from the tree.
meaning: Children observe daily and — in their behaviour — often follow the example of their parents.

translation: Truth creates hatred. (Terence, Andria 68)
The truth will set you free. (Gospel of John, 8:32)
Time discloses the truth.
Truth conquers all.
He who perseveres, conquers.
equivalent: Persevere and never fear; By perseverance the snail reached the arc.
Look before you leap, for snakes among sweet flowers do creep.

translation: The man fled, and he will fight anew.
equivalent: Source for meaning of Martin H. Manser (2007). The Facts on File Dictionary of Proverbs. Infobase Publishing. p. 123. ISBN 978-0-8160-6673-5.
meaning: "It is wiser to withdraw from a situation that you cannot win than to go on fighting and lose – by a strategic retreat you can return to the battle or argument with renewed energy at a later date."

origin: Viveri bis, vitâ posse priori frui.
translation: It is to live twice to be able to enjoy the retrospect of your past life.
Virtue survives the grave.
A fox may change its skin but never its character. - Suetonius

equivalent: Advice most needed is the least heeded.

origin: The Perfect Heresy: The Revolutionary Life and Death of the Medieval Cathars
